data.message:
Fix a couple of narrowing conversions and deactivate the check for now

We do have a couple of narrowing conversions left, but we are pretty
sure, they won't affect anything. Therefore, we decided to deactivate
the check for now. With a later version of clang-tidy we can use NOLINT
blocks to deactivate this check for sections of code.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Replace boost with new C++ language features

Most changes are straight-forward and have a direct correspondence in
newer C++. The std::threads should have an additional plausibility check
before joining, and one before creation to avoid assertions during
initialization.
Infinite loops in the thread function must be stopped from outside
before joining. This seems to have changed w.r.t boost::thread, which
could be interrupted.

data.author: Felix Exner
data.message: remove redundant break entries

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Reset feedback polling thread upon connection

Our feedback thread might already be running through previous calls to
`getFirmwareInfo()`. We now reset the thread if that's the case.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Drop explicit realtime support for serial communication

This functionality is mostly legacy code from the times when
`icl_comm_serial` should support any possible hardware on any possible
OS and use case. Since we are now specifically targeting the Schunk SVH,
I don't see a real benefit for keeping this.  This makes maintenance
much easier. Let's get that back only if we really need this.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message: Remove more unused `icl_core` includes

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Use std features for remaining time measurements

This is a continuation of commit 7cfcb144.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Correctly close `SVHSerialInterface`

We now check for intitialized members before shutting everything down.
This also fixes our unit tests that segfaulted with the last commit.

Its interesting that this did not happen while testing with the real
hardware.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Remodel the `SVHReceiveThread` with std::thread

The `SVHReceiveThread` is now a *normal* class, which is instantiated as a
member in client code. Users then call its `run()` method in a separate
thread and its `stop()` method before joining with the main thread.
This is cleaner and easier to understand than the previous approach of
inheriting from a thread class.

We also replace time measurement with `std::chrono` features.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Use `std::chrono` for time measurement

Replacing icl_core's `TimeSpan` also motivated to use `std::thread`
for polling feedback, which made `SVHFeedbackPollingThread` as a custom
thread class obsolete.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message: Replace `icl_core` sleeps with new C++ features

data.message: Update readme with infos on `dialout` Linux group

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Fix library relocations for install

We must make sure that the linker finds `libsvh-serial` and
`libsvh-websocket` when linking against our package from both the
*install* and the *build* directory.

This fix sets the `RPATH` accordingly.
See tips
[here](https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/community/-/wikis/doc/cmake/RPATH-handling)

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Add installation options

Also unify the target names a little.
Users can now install this library and use it with modern CMake
conventions. All they need to do is

`find_package(schunk_svh_library REQUIRED)`

and

```cmake
target_link_libraries(some-target
  Schunk::svh-library
)
```

See merge request hardware-drivers/driver_svh!13

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Use default `ttyUSB0` in tests

It makes sense to configure the tests for a single Schunk SVH, which will
appear as `ttyUSB0`.

Also add a timeout for `test_svh_receive`. I'm currently not sure how
else that is supposed to eventually finish in a CI-based setting.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Reactivate unit tests

We use the boost framework as before.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Fix undefined symbols in library targets

We had undefined references to
- Boost thread
- libzmq
- and some `instance()` method provided by the logging macros.

We find `libzmq` with `PkgConfig` because there's no straight-forward
cmake find script.
Calling `ldd -r` on every library target now behaves as expected.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message: Fix compiler deprecation warnings

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Include `icl_comm_websocket` into this package

The functionalities of `icl_comm_websocket` were specifically developed
for the Schunk SVH driver. We now get them back into this repository and
drop the dependency of `icl_comm`.

The files' content is not changed except for adjustments to the
includes, full name qualifications of some types, and the
websocket-specific preprocessor directives.

Jsoncpp is currently included in cmake with `PckConfig` and zmq seems to
ship with latest Ubuntu versions. See
[here](https://packages.ubuntu.com/search?keywords=libzmq)

Let's see if this robustly works on *Bionic* and *Focal* once we have
the CI pipeline running.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Switch to modern CMake

This is now a modern CMake package.
We use CMake 3.10, which is Bionic's (Ubuntu 18.04) shipping version.

The package's primary target is `schunk_svh` (`libschunk_svh.so`) that
will be the core library for ROS1 and ROS2 drivers.
Other libraries are meant to stay internal.

There are still two system dependencies:
- `icl_comm` (for `icl_comm_websocket`)
- and on `icl_core`.
Both will be included or replaced in later commits.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message: Adapt includes using the new package structure

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Reorganize package structure

This package will grow with the inclusion and additions of the icl_comm
and icl_core libraries and possible replacements. A new package
structure makes sense here.
We also properly separate header files and implementation files.

We now have
- `control` for the control and core driver related things
- `serial` for the serial interface and related functionality
- Other files stay top-level for now

We only move the files without modifying them to keep the Git blame
functionality.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message: Add minimal readme for build instructions

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message: Adapt setup to new test file names

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Rename test files for `svh_driver`

The `Test` postfix is more consistent with the `serial_interface` and more descriptive
that the `ts_` prefix.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Move test folder outside of src

I want a clear distinction for both.

I'm not touching these files besides moving them to keep the Git blame
functionality intact.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Integrate `icl_comm_serial` into this package

The functionality is sufficiently light-weight and there are no further
transient dependencies apart from the usual `icl_core` components.

We re-used the `DriverSVH` logger macro definition.
Let's see if that's enough or if we want serial communication specific
logging later.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Move `ByteOrderConversion` into this repo

This component was developed for the SVH driver but was placed inside
the `icl_comm` for possible further usage.
We get that back and provide that natively inside the SVH driver.

This allows us to remove the generic `icl_comm` dependency.

data.author: Robert Wilbrandt
data.message:
Fix bug in firmware info retrieving

The m_firmware_info variable was uninitialized, which could lead to not
actually requesting the firmware info from the hardware (leading to a
random version number). By explicitly setting the version numbers to zero,
this request is forced. This also ensures that the correct configuration
is loaded, as the version number is used for deciding which
configuration to use.

data.author: Georg Heppner
data.message:
Winner of the PID Award 2014! PID Values of all the Joints for S5FH
These values represent the Best values after over 10 hours of iterative
testing and reverse engineering! They should work an all reasonable operational
S5FH hands.
BEWARE: There is still a Bug in the Low Level PID Controller cascade of
Position and current controller (within the HW controller).
This is however not fixable by this
software and can not be averted.
Also: Added some debugging options and left in some more ore less ugly code
that needs to be cleaned after automatica

data.author: Georg Heppner
